title.justification: The title precisely encapsulates the core method and contribution described in the paper: using neural networks to create semantic surface maps.
title.quote: We present an automated technique for computing a map between two genus-zero shapes, which matches semantically corresponding regions to one another.

extractions.description: This paper presents an automated method for computing semantic mappings between pairs of genus-zero 3D shapes, optimizing semantic correspondences using features distilled from pre-trained vision transformers (ViT).

type.justification: The paper describes empirical experiments to validate the proposed method, including quantitative and qualitative evaluations.
type.quote: Through quantitative and qualitative experiments, we evaluate our ability to match upright object pairs with varying levels of isometry for objects from the same semantic class and across different ones.

name.justification: The paper focuses on using vision transformers and image-based correspondences to compute maps between 3D shapes.
name.quote: To overcome the lack of annotated training data, we distill semantic matches from pre-trained vision models.

name.justification: The core contribution of the paper deals with analyzing shapes to identify semantically corresponding regions and creating maps from these correspondences.
name.quote: Our core contribution is an approach for computing a semantic map that matches semantically corresponding points to one another.

name.justification: The pre-trained Vision Transformer is used to generate semantic correspondences between 3D shapes.
name.quote: Thanks to pre-trained ViT models which can identify semantically corresponding points across shape renderings.

name.justification: Used to evaluate the method’s performance on isometric deformations.
name.quote: We randomly select 30 pairs from FAUST, containing isometric deformations and pose variations of human shapes.

name.justification: Used to evaluate method’s performance on non-isometric deformations.
name.quote: We choose 30 random same-category shape pairs from SHREC07, containing non-isometric deformations across multiple categories of shapes.

name.justification: Used to evaluate method’s performance across a mix of isometric and non-isometric deformations.
name.quote: We also extract 30 random shape pairs among the listed test set of SHREC19 from Dyke et al., containing a mix of isometric and non-isometric deformations.

name.justification: Used to evaluate method performance considering pose variations.
name.quote: We use FAUST, SCAPE, and TOSCA. To ablate the effects of rendering settings and rotation, we use FAUST; 3DBiCar, which comprise a variety of textured shapes; and SHREC15, which contain significant nonisometric-variations, with manually-annotated sparse correspondences.
